body: I think it is smarter to fix this at the source?

Looks good. Thanks @mbrukman for the feedback on the style. Also the Flake8 test is failing.

I have one question, what are the changes to the docstring? This probably give conflicts with other merge requests.

Thanks @Acehaidrey I really like this PR, this will make debugging a lot easier.

One concern that I'm having, is security. If you have access to Airflow, you can get data out more easily. But this should be handled on a higher level.

Thanks @Fokko! 
And regarding the security concern, you are right they could. Is there any where you guys are keeping notes on the higher level plan, that I could take a look? I'd be willing to help as well
Follow up fix: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2961
PTAL @bolkedebruin @ashb @Acehaidrey

@r39132 No, I don't have at the moment. The fix is not simple as I expected, specially that I found other bugs in the sla module. I'm ok with this PR as a temporary solution till I have a complete and well tested fix.

So after a pretty extensive rebasing we've gotten the PR down to 21 commits (the PR is currently broken, but shouldn't be too hard to fix). The previous branch now lives [here](https://github.com/bloomberg/airflow/tree/airflow-kubernetes-executor-old), so we can always refer back as we move forward. This should help us get this project up and merged soon!

Next steps:

1. Get the article out about the k8s operator so we can encourage people to start using it
2. work with @grantnicholas and @benjigoldberg to fix remaining bugs

I'm not sure this works as intended:

```
In [5]: import airflow.operators

In [7]: airflow.operators.BashOperator
/Users/ash/code/python/incubator-airflow/airflow/utils/helpers.py:351: DeprecationWarning: Importing BashOperator directly from <module 'airflow.operators' from '/Users/ash/code/python/incubator-airflow/airflow/operators/__init__.py'> has been deprecated. Please import from '<module 'airflow.operators' from '/Users/ash/code/python/incubator-airflow/airflow/operators/__init__.py'>.[operator_module]' instead. Support for direct imports will be dropped entirely in Airflow 2.0.
  DeprecationWarning)
Out[7]: bash_operator.BashOperator

In [8]: airflow.operators.sensors
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-8-3cadeea94026> in <module>()
----> 1 airflow.operators.sensors

~/code/python/incubator-airflow/airflow/utils/helpers.py in __getattr__(self, attribute)
    379             return loaded_attribute
    380
--> 381         raise AttributeError
```

~Wait am I testing the wrong thing -- and `airflow.operators.sensors.S3KeySensor` is the new name or the old one?~ Yes, this is the new name.

Testing with `from airflow.operators.sensors import S3KeySensor` which we use in a current DAG I don't get any import warning as I would have expected. It does continue to work though which is a plus.

Thanks @ivanwirawan, looks good

Hi @andscoop, first of all, thank you for your contribution. Testing the operator is required, even if it isn't a test that will take care of all the edge cases. The most common way of testing this is by mocking s3/mongo. Also make sure that the CI passes (which is failing right now).

What is important that we merge a clean commit in the end. Since it is a single unit of work, it should be a single commit.

Cheers, Fokko

Hi @yati-sagade, this PR makes sense to me. It is related to the code @bolkedebruin wrote. Wouldn't be `airflow test` more appropriate to test the dag instead of `airflow run`, what's your opinion on that?
I agree with @bolkedebruin, we should look into what's causing this.
Please fix the CI
Nice one, thanks!
The CI is not happy
Thanks for spotting the typo
Thanks for spotting the typo
I know :-)
Can you have a look at this? @Fokko @criccomini @jgao54
Please squash the two commits, then I'll merge right away
@l1990790120 @gwax I am running my pipeline on EMR and any task longer than 1 hour fails because of this. Any reason why this was not merged into master?
Updated with squashed commit.
Thanks @ji-han, by squashing the commit, it is much easier to keep track of the unit of work. If something is wrong, it is easier to revert to commit if necessary. Thanks!
Thanks!

@idlecool I am not an Airflow committer. I help review in the hopes of reducing the burden on official committers in the hopes of getting more PRs through the process.

There is a moderate backlog at this point. You might be better off maintaining your own fork with cherry-picked commits for the hot fixes you need.
Ok. Thanks @gwax Posting a screenshot just as a proof that this issues still exists.
@kaxil I am waiting for @jgao54 to take a look. Should happen in 2-3 days. Sit tight.
@fenglu-g FYI
@mbrukman, @Fokko Done

@Fokko , already update the readme as suggested.
May I know who will do the merging?

Hello,

Could we move forward on that PR. I just redo it on a fork before finding this PR...
So firstly
- A mysql index can never use a nullable column.
- If you look to the commit it is more a typo fix than something else. The column is set as nullable=false for postgresql as well
- If you look to older script it is already set as nullable=false for those two table. So without the PR, it looks to a erroneous change to a nullable column, what is obviously forbidden.

So we can assume this PR is fine. So the real question is why travis is failing ?
The truth is probably that:
- this PR is fine
- travis test is working before this PR only because the database migration failure does not makes travis failed but avoid the running of something else that screw the build

On my box, when the PR is apply, the initialization goes further. It even show me that fernet dependency was not installed.... But it fails once I enable a dag with a:
```
_mysql_exceptions.IntegrityError: (1062, "Duplicate entry 'print_context-timezone_bxl_10m-2018-01-24 14:26:10.137224' for key 'PRIMARY'")
```
So clearly the PR make it not functional.

But on the other hand, without this PR makes part of the initialization skipped.
```
airflow_1  | sqlalchemy.exc.DataError: (_mysql_exceptions.DataError) (1171, 'All parts of a PRIMARY KEY must be NOT NULL; if you need NULL in a key, use UNIQUE instead') [SQL: 'ALTER TABLE sla_miss MODIFY execution_date TIMESTAMP(6) NULL']
airflow_1  | [2018-01-24 14:42:26,997] {{driver.py:120}} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python3.5/lib2to3/Grammar.txt
airflow_1  | [2018-01-24 14:42:27,030] {{driver.py:120}} INFO - Generating grammar tables from /usr/lib/python3.5/lib2to3/PatternGrammar.txt
airflow_1  | [2018-01-24 14:42:27,148] {{__init__.py:45}} INFO - Using executor LocalExecutor
```

So we should find the bug behind the bug. I will continue to search, but since I am new to this project I am not sure I will find it shortly.

@fenglu-g Thanks for the review!

LGTM
Merged.
@idlecool As another workaround, I couldn't remember the specifics but we were able to get around with EMR settings as well.

Hello,

I manage to fix the issue. It is caused by how alchemy/alembic manage timestamp.
For MySQL default value is mandatory for a NOT NULL column 
(read https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/timestamp-initialization.html). 

For alchemy/alembic, if you do not set the value it will use current_time for create but also for update:
```
  `execution_date` timestamp(6) NOT NULL DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(6) ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP(6),
```

To avoid this you need to specify the default value.
To share the fix I did create a new PR. Feel free to adapt this one or to use mine, I do not care: 
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2969

Cheers,
Cinhil
closing
Closing

Hi @criccomini No problem. The only reason I am pushing is to avoid any possible conflicts due to merge of any newer PR relating BigQuery Hook.
@bolkedebruin can you take a look?

Hey @Fokko thanks for reviewing. Indeed `airflow test` is used more than `run` to actually test tasks, but for example, the scheduler enqueues a `airflow run --local ...` command to the executors, and these are then run verbatim by the executors. In my foray into the scheduler and executor guts to fix [AIRFLOW-2001](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-2001), I felt the need to trigger the whole flow (as opposed to locally running a ti with `airflow test`), especially since a promising fix for that issue looks like treating different nonzero exit codes from the `airflow run --local ...` command executed on workers differently (currently any nonzero code means error). What do you think?

```
    c TIMESTAMP NULL,
    d TIMESTAMP NOT NULL
)
```

@Fokko please check this one too

Hello,

I run a default MySQL Docker 5.7 latest image.

Here the variable value:
```
Variable_name	Value
explicit_defaults_for_timestamp	OFF
```

You will see on https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/server-system-variables.html that this variable is deprecated since 5.6.6 and default value is OFF.
But the documentation is funnier : it basically says it is OFF, but OFF is not standard and that the non standard behavior will be removed in next versions, so to be future proof you need to be ON.

CREATE TABLE returns "Invalid default value for 'd'"
If I add DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP to d I have:
```
CREATE TABLE `ts_test` (
  `a` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
  `b` int(11) NOT NULL,
  `c` timestamp NULL DEFAULT NULL,
  `d` timestamp NOT NULL DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1
```

I did not change Alchemy version so it is the version specified by setup.py.

ok. From this I think the original change by @edgarRd was the right fix. In addition we should specify that for MySQL the setting should be turned on.

Your duplicate key seems to stem from something else. Can you include the trace back (python) for that?

Interesting btw that the create table syntax didn’t work. It is used by sql alchemy to show what happens and works fine on Mariadb 10.2, although it adds the default ‘0000-00-00...’ when creating it, if the setting is off.

The duplicate key is caused by the onupdate that will change the execution_date and obviously mess up the primary key. I just tested with the explicit-defaults-for-timestamp to ON and it works. So I am fine with the other PR with additional documentation about the MySQL variable.
